stream_context.summary: Kaze reworks a frustrating sub-area in Course 2 (Divine Dino Domain), replacing an earlier “leaf boat/autoscroll-ish” concept with a more open platforming playground. He blockouts geometry first (stairs, vines/roots, traversal routes), then begins thinking about UV mapping and later art pass. The stream also surfaces technical instability (crashes/slow loads), a known water crash risk due to outdated step-function support, and a deeper limitation of the decomp workflow: all areas load at once because RoamManager is binary-only, costing RAM. Broader project updates include Course 12 being essentially finished off-stream (pending Zeina animations/signage), Course 13 planning (mysterious ice castle—needs a boss), Course 14 partially built in secret, and Course 15 still undecided.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains meaningful production status updates (game ~80% done; Course 12 nearly shippable), concrete pipeline philosophy (blockout → fun → aesthetics), and a key technical constraint of decomp-based hacks (area loading/RAM) plus crash risks around water/step functions.

findings.summary: Kaze says the project is just above 80% complete and that only three courses remain, positioning the game in late-stage production.
Course 12 was finished mostly off-stream and is close to shippable, but still needs a few Zeina animations integrated plus some sign work.
findings.quote: I finished Course 12 off-stream… There’s a few more animations from Zeina I have to put in the game… Oh yeah, and some signs.

findings.summary: Course planning is clarified: Course 13 is intended to be a suspenseful/mysterious ice castle; Course 14 is a “space arcade”; Course 15 is currently undecided (with chat suggesting a generic lava level or rainbow-style finale).

In Course 2’s Divine Dino Domain rework, Kaze abandons a prior “leaf boats”/almost-autoscroll segment because it felt bad to play, replacing it with a freer platforming playground focused on movement options and recovery routes (e.g., stairs to escape water on both sides).
findings.quote: I realized the section sucked. So now we have a little bit of a platforming playground here.

findings.summary: Kaze reiterates a consistent level-production method: block out traversal with simple primitives until the jumping feels good, then do aesthetics/UVs later.
findings.quote: Right now we just want the platforming to be fun. And then we can think about the visuals.

findings.summary: The build shows instability: unusually long loading times and repeated crashes; Kaze suspects “something’s wrong with this level” and notes water interactions are especially dangerous right now.
findings.quote: We have quite long loading times… something’s wrong for sure.

findings.summary: Water is currently hazardous because it hasn’t been updated to the new step function; old step functions are no longer fully supported, so entering water can crash the game.
findings.quote: Water hasn’t been updated to the new step function yet… being in water can just crash the game.

findings.summary: Kaze explains a decomp-specific limitation: the current setup loads all areas at once. A tool called RoamManager could load areas one-by-one (saving RAM) but it’s built for binary hacks and doesn’t work with decomp. Solving it would require linker-script work he hasn’t learned yet.
findings.quote: It does [load them all in one go]… RoamManager… is made for binary, so we can’t use it with decomp… if you wanted to load the areas one by one, you need to learn a lot of linker script that I haven’t learned yet.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions modifying earlier contributor code: he recently changed AkiDev’s Chain Chomp code to support adding a second Chain Chomp in another level, showing ongoing refactors and reuse of prior systems.
findings.quote: I changed your Chain Chomp code… because I wanted a second Chain Chomp in a different level.

findings.summary: Kaze says he avoids Patreon bonuses because it could create legal trouble with Nintendo, indicating a deliberate risk-management approach to monetization/benefits.
findings.quote: I also don’t give out any Patreon bonuses… because that might get me in legal trouble with Nintendo.

findings.summary: Kaze has started Course 14 but won’t show a completed area because “Eiza” asked him not to (it’s part of a competition/pack), so some development is happening privately to preserve a planned reveal.
findings.quote: I have a whole area done on Course 14 that I can’t show you guys. Because Eiza doesn’t want me to show it.

findings.summary: He complains that the Parallel emulator causes workflow friction (frequent updates, slower hotkey behavior, ROM-specific issues not seen on real N64, and controller problems), implying testing/QA depends on multiple emulators and real hardware.
findings.quote: There’s a bunch of issues… in Parallel that are not there on N64… and then… my controller doesn’t work on it.

zeina.summary: Zeina’s animations are a remaining dependency for shipping Course 12; Kaze frames the remaining work as simple integration tasks once her assets are ready.

A humorous but revealing personal/professional overlap: Zeina cut Kaze’s hair, the clipper guard came off, and he ended up with a visible bald line—prompting him to wear a hat/beanie for much of the stream.
zeina.quote: Zaina slipped with the hair clippers and just put a bald spot there.

findings.summary: AkiDev is acknowledged as the author of existing Chain Chomp code that Kaze recently altered for reuse (supporting a second Chain Chomp in another level), highlighting the project’s evolving codebase and inheritance of prior contributor systems.
Eiza influences public communication/reveals: Kaze withholds showing a finished Course 14 area because Eiza wants it kept secret as part of a competition/pack.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The day where you can play this game will one day come—unless someone murders me. If someone murders me, it was a Nintendo employee.
memorable_quotes.context: Dark humor that captures both the long arc of finishing a major ROM hack and the ever-present anxiety about Nintendo/legal pressure, framed in Kaze’s characteristic comedic tone.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Right now we just want the platforming to be fun. And then we can think about the visuals.
memorable_quotes.context: Clear statement of his level-design pipeline and priorities—function and feel first, art pass second.

key_stories.title: Course 2 sub-area redesign: removing a bad autoscroll-like segment
key_stories.summary: Kaze revisits a previously-built sub-area in Divine Dino Domain and decides the earlier concept (leaf boats pushing you through a quasi-autoscroll) simply isn’t fun. He restructures it into a more open platforming playground with optional routes, recovery staircases out of water, and planned setpieces like a Yoshi-god statue and red coin challenge.
key_stories.challenge: A section of Course 2 felt annoying and unfun, with punishments for falling into water and movement constraints.
key_stories.process: He blockouts new traversal with primitives (stairs, spiral staircase ideas, vines/roots), playtests jump flow, and defers cohesive aesthetics/UV mapping until the movement reads well.
key_stories.outcome: A new layout direction is established; remaining tasks mentioned include placing the Yoshi-god statue, finalizing routes, and then proceeding to UV mapping and art style decisions.
key_stories.key_quote: I realized the section sucked. So now we have a little bit of a platforming playground here.

key_stories.title: Decomp limitation: area loading and RAM cost (RoamManager vs linker scripts)
key_stories.summary: While discussing long loads and general level stability, Kaze explains a structural technical limitation: in their decomp setup, all areas load at once. He contrasts this with RoamManager (used in binary hacks) which can load areas one-by-one, but can’t be used here. Fixing it would require deeper linker-script work.
key_stories.challenge: High RAM usage and less efficient loading because decomp workflow lacks an equivalent to binary-area streaming tools.
key_stories.process: Kaze identifies the known solution path (linker scripts / alternative asset-loading strategy) but notes it’s outside his current expertise and toolchain.
key_stories.outcome: The constraint remains and becomes an interview-worthy technical theme: what decomp enables vs what it complicates compared to classic binary ROM hacking.
key_stories.key_quote: RoamManager… is made for binary, so we can’t use it with decomp… you need to learn a lot of linker script that I haven’t learned yet.

key_stories.title: Crash risk around water during engine transitions (step function mismatch)
key_stories.summary: Kaze warns chat that water is currently dangerous because it hasn’t been updated to a newer step function, while the older step functions are no longer fully supported. As a result, entering water can crash the game, shaping how he tests the level during the session.
key_stories.challenge: Ongoing engine/physics refactors create transitional periods where certain environments (water) become unstable.
key_stories.process: He avoids water during playtests, flags it as a known technical debt item, and attributes some instability to the current state of system transitions.
key_stories.outcome: A clear short-term development constraint is established: avoid water-heavy testing until the step-function migration is completed.
key_stories.key_quote: Being in water can just crash the game.

open_questions.context: Kaze says decomp currently loads all areas at once; RoamManager (binary) can stream areas but is incompatible; solving it would require linker-script knowledge.
questions: How much RAM is currently being lost by loading all areas at once, and what concrete constraints does that impose on RTYI (textures, geo complexity, enemy counts, music)?
Did the team ever prototype a decomp-compatible alternative to RoamManager, or consider writing a new tool?
What specifically in the decomp build system/linker scripts would need to change to allow per-area loading, and is that a realistic goal before release?
How did this limitation influence level design (e.g., fewer unique assets per course, reuse of materials, smaller sub-areas)?

open_questions.topic: Water crash risk and step-function migration
open_questions.context: Water uses an old step function that’s no longer fully supported; entering water can crash the game. This suggests a larger engine refactor mid-production.
questions: What is the ‘new step function’ migration (what changed, why was it necessary), and what remains to update water to it?
How often do crashes still occur on real N64 vs emulators, and what’s the debug process for water-related crashes?
Did this instability force any design changes (fewer water segments, different punishments for falling, extra escape staircases)?

open_questions.context: Kaze states Course 13 will be a suspenseful ice castle and explicitly says they still need a boss concept for it.
questions: What emotions or references define the ‘mysterious/suspenseful’ tone of the ice castle, and what boss would reinforce that theme?
Do you prefer a mechanical/platforming boss, a puzzle boss, or a spectacle boss for Course 13—and why?
What existing systems/AI (from earlier bosses or enemies) could be reused to build the ice boss efficiently without breaking performance on N64?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he built an entire area in Course 14 but cannot show it because Eiza requested secrecy as part of a competition/pack.
questions: What is the ‘comp pack’ and what commitment did you make about not showing Course 14 content?
How does building a level ‘in secret’ affect iteration speed, feedback from chat, and coordination with artists/composer?
Is this secrecy tied to a release beat/marketing plan for RTYI or a separate competition deliverable?

open_questions.topic: Late-stage warp/order changes causing outdated level pathways
open_questions.context: Kaze notes that changing level order made at least one warp (submarine → dome) out of date, implying ongoing restructuring even late in development.
questions: How often do you reorder courses/warps this late, and what drives those decisions (difficulty curve, story beats, technical needs)?
What tooling/checklist do you use to keep warps consistent after reorders, and how do you test for broken pathways?
Was the warp change purely organizational, or did it reflect a broader redesign of progression through the hub/overworld?
